title: Racist abuse forces abandonment of Haringey vs Yeovil FA Cup tie
text:
Douglas Pajeta was racially abused during Yeovil’s FA Cup tie against Harringey (Picture: Twitter)

Haringey Borough’s FA Cup clash against Yeovil was abandoned after goalkeeper Valery Pajetat was racially abused.

With the score level at 0-0, Yeovil were given the chance to break the deadlock when they were awarded a penalty.

There was a lengthy delay before the spot-kick was taken and both the referee and Yeovil captain went over to speak to the fans behind the goal.

Yeovil’s Rhys Murphy eventually scored the penalty but just two minutes later, Haringey manager Tom Loizou led his team off the pitch after Pajetat reported he had suffered racial abuse, was spat at and had objects thrown at him.

"We're sometimes quick to get on our high horse at times and point the finger. We still have a huge problem in our leagues." After allegations of racial abuse aimed at the Haringey Borough goalkeeper by Yeovil fans, the hosts have walked off.#BTSportScore pic.twitter.com/TnS4hPhcFY — BT Sport Score (@btsportscore) October 19, 2019

Security are understood to have identified the fans they felt were responsible for the abuse but those in question were reluctant to leave Coles Park ground.

Half an hour later, the game was eventually called off but both teams did re-emerge from the dressing rooms.

The Haringey and Yeovil players came out onto the pitch together and as a show of solidarity, applauded the Haringey fans as one group.
